@carrickdb not necessarily though if the initial input buffer was created without null termination and written right up to the boundary - as you say we can't even assume that :)
@carrickdb If thereâ€™s no null youâ€™d eventually hit uninitialized memory and crash with no risk of code exec in your count loop.

@carrickdb You'd not trust the calling function; your function would count the bytes of the input buffer (assuming null termination). Problem is you'd need to call an *alloc if inline assembly is not allowed under terms of the question and you'd not be able to trust that.

@carrickdb Rather than the calling function supplying the output buffer, the function youâ€™re writing could provide it based upon length of input buffer? Assuming you also avoid integer wraps etc, too. ğŸ¤·â€â™‚ï¸
